head.headtext: Testimony at a previous judicial proceeding

para.paratext: The testimony of a witness, now unavailable,[1] given under oath on a former trial where the issues and parties were substantially the same as the present trial will be received in evidence as an exception to the hearsay rule.
O.C.G.A. § 24-8-804(b)(1) provides:

Testimony given as a witness at another hearing of the same or a different proceeding, or in a deposition taken in compliance with law in the course of the same or another proceeding, if the party against whom the testimony is now offered, or, in a civil proceeding, a predecessor in interest, had an opportunity and similar motive to develop the testimony by direct, cross, or redirect examination. If deposition testimony is admissible under either the rules stated in Code Section 9-11-32 or this Code section, it shall be admissible at trial in accordance with the rules under which it was offered.

The witness who testified at the former trial must be unavailable at the present trial to admit the former testimony. The usual statement is that the witness must be deceased, disqualified, or inaccessible.

There are many things that can be said to render the witness unavailable.[2] Death of the witness is too clear to need discussion. If the mental condition of the witness would render him incompetent,[3] or if he is incompetent from old age and infirmity, he is unavailable.[4] If the witness is out of the state so that he is outside the jurisdiction of the court, he is unavailable.[5] Merely being out of the county is not enough.[6]

Naturally, the accessibility of the witness and the diligence of the party seeking to use the former testimony in searching for him lie within the sound discretion of the judge.[7] If the witness cannot be found after a diligent search, he is unavailable.[8] Where the witness has escaped from the penitentiary, he was unavalable.[9] Where the witness has become incompetent under the survivor statute due to the death of the adverse party after the former testimony, he is unavailable, and the former testimony is admissible.[10] If a proper showing of due diligence is not made, it would be error to admit the former testimony.[11]

One of the best discussions of inaccessibility (unavailability) generally appears in Tanner v. State.[12] This was a case of first impression as to what might be called “temporary” inaccessibility. Here the witness was sick, and a showing was made that the witness was unable to testify at that term of court. There was no evidence to show any reasonable probability that she would never be able to testify. The Georgia Supreme Court reviewed the conflicting views in other jurisdictions and held that the former testimony was not admissible and that a continuance should have been requested and granted.

In Bolling v. State,[13] the Georgia Supreme Court found that “unavailability as a witness” occurs when a witness is absent from the hearing and the proponent of the statement was unable to procure the attendance by process or other reasonable means, and expressly considered federal appellate court decisions in interpreting the rule's counterpart in Fed. Evid. R. 804. Accordingly, the Court ruled that the proponent must show that reasonable, good-faith efforts to locate the witness were made, which is reviewed on appeal on an abuse of discretion standard.

Perkins v. Edwards[14] involved the caveat of a will. One of the attesting witnesses had testified in the court of ordinary. On the trial in superior court a physician testified that she was ill and could not testify for two or three days. It was held that the trial judge had not abused his discretion in admitting her former testimony. The Tanner case was not cited or considered. There is some indication that due to the problem of confrontation there must be a stronger showing of unavailability in criminal cases.
Where the witness claims the privilege against self-incrimination at the second trial, his “testimony” is unavailable and the former testimony is admissible.[15]

In Lee v. State,[16] the witness was divorced from the defendant and testified at the preliminary hearing. They remarried before the trial, and she claimed her privilege not to testify. The state properly introduced her testimony from the preliminary hearing.
“Unavailability” is defined in O.C.G.A. § 24-8-804(a) as a situation in which the declarant:
(1) Is exempted by ruling of the court on the ground of privilege from testifying concerning the subject matter of the declarant's statement;
(2) Persists in refusing to testify concerning the subject matter of the declarant's statement despite an order of the court to do so;
(3) Testifies to a lack of memory of the subject matter of the declarant's statement;
(4) Is unable to be present or to testify at the hearing because of death or then existing physical or mental illness or infirmity; or

(5) Is absent from the hearing and the proponent of the statement has been unable to procure the declarant's attendance or, in the case of exceptions under paragraph (2), (3), or (4) of subsection (b) of this Code section, the declarant's attendance or testimony, by process or other reasonable means.
Under former law, the term was “legally inaccessible.”
McCormick on Evidence § 255 (6th ed.).
Estill v. Citizens' & Southern Bank, 153 Ga. 618, 113 S.E. 552 (1922).
Central R. & Banking Co. v. Murray, 97 Ga. 326, 22 S.E. 972 (1895).

Eagle & Phenix Mfg. Co. v. Welch, 61 Ga. 444, 1878 WL 2907 (1878); Smith v. State, 147 Ga. 689, 95 S.E. 281, 15 A.L.R. 490 (1918); Norris v. State, 58 Ga. App. 399, 198 S.E. 714 (1938). In Brown v. State, 245 Ga. 588, 266 S.E.2d 198 (1980), the doctor who had testified at the first trial refused to return from another state that did not have the Uniform Act to Secure the Attendance of Witnesses from Without the State, so his testimony at the former trial was admissible. See also Bragg v. State, 279 Ga. 156, 611 S.E.2d 17 (2005).
Taylor v. State, 126 Ga. 557, 55 S.E. 474 (1906).

O.C.G.A. § 24-1-104(a); Sheppard v. State, 167 Ga. 326, 145 S.E. 654 (1928); Rini v. State, 236 Ga. 715, 225 S.E.2d 234 (1976); LaCount v. State, 237 Ga. 181, 227 S.E.2d 31 (1976); Hewell v. State, 139 Ga. App. 622, 229 S.E.2d 92 (1976), judgment rev'd on other grounds, 238 Ga. 578, 234 S.E.2d 497 (1977); Gibson v. State, 160 Ga. App. 615, 287 S.E.2d 595 (1981); Jones v. State, 250 Ga. 166, 296 S.E.2d 598 (1982); Kesler v. Veal, 165 Ga. App. 475, 300 S.E.2d 217 (1983).

In Riley v. State, 237 Ga. 124, 226 S.E.2d 922 (1976), it was held that the showing of the unavailability of the witness is a procedural matter, and under the facts of the case such a showing was waived.
See also Dillingham v. State, 275 Ga. 665, 571 S.E.2d 777 (2002); Carter v. State, 266 Ga. App. 691, 598 S.E.2d 76 (2004).
Robinson v. State, 128 Ga. 254, 57 S.E. 315 (1907). See also Barnes v. State, 256 Ga. 370, 349 S.E.2d 387 (1986); Flowers v. Union Carbide Corp., 271 Ga. App. 438, 610 S.E.2d 109 (2005).
Burns v. State, 191 Ga. 60, 11 S.E.2d 350 (1940).
Georgia Chemical Works v. Malcolm, 186 Ga. 275, 197 S.E. 763 (1938).

Gaither v. State, 227 Ga. 668, 182 S.E.2d 434 (1971); Whatley v. State, 230 Ga. 523, 198 S.E.2d 176 (1973); Robertson v. State, 124 Ga. App. 119, 183 S.E.2d 47 (1971); Hewell v. State, 136 Ga. App. 420, 221 S.E.2d 219 (1975). In Todd v. State, 243 Ga. 539, 255 S.E.2d 5 (1979), the defendant could not rely on the fact that the witness' name was on the state's witness list, so had not shown due diligence. See Smith v. State, 247 Ga. 453, 276 S.E.2d 633 (1981).
Bolling v. State, 300 Ga. 694, 797 S.E.2d 872 (2017).
Perkins v. Edwards, 228 Ga. 470, 186 S.E.2d 109 (1971).

Park v. State, 225 Ga. 618, 170 S.E.2d 687 (1969), judgment vacated in part on other grounds, 408 U.S. 935, 92 S. Ct. 2845, 33 L. Ed. 2d 749 (1972); Lingerfelt v. State, 231 Ga. 354, 201 S.E.2d 445 (1973); Bennett v. State, 231 Ga. 458, 202 S.E.2d 99 (1973) (disapproved of on other grounds by, Crowder v. State, 237 Ga. 141, 227 S.E.2d 230 (1976)) and (overruled on other grounds by, Howard v. State, 237 Ga. 471, 228 S.E.2d 860 (1976)); 45 A. L. R. 2d 1354.
In Wiseman v. State, 249 Ga. 559, 292 S.E.2d 670 (1982), the defendant's wife had testified at the commitment hearing, but asserted her privilege at trial. Her prior testimony was properly admitted.
